children.text: A
new study
finds that the expanded Child Tax Credit — implemented last year as a key part of President Biden’s American Rescue Plan — did not negatively impact employment among adults with children.
The findings completely disprove West Virginia Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin’s rationale for opposing the cash payments.
Find out how and much more in today’s Midday Poster below, exclusively for supporting subscribers.
TODAY’S QUOTE:
“Perhaps the most egregious thing we are taught is that we should just be really good at what's already possible, to leave the impossible alone.” — adrienne maree brown in her book Emergent Strategy.
TODAY’S READS:
Federal Grand Jury Indicts Former JEA Executives On Conspiracy, Wire Fraud
J&J’s Controversial Prison Testing Resurfaces In Baby Powder Lawsuits
How Did This Many Deaths Become Normal?
Inside FDA’s ‘Forever Chemicals’ Catastrophe
BlackRock Tells Oil Regulator: Ignore Our CEO’s Climate Pledges
Lead From Gasoline Blunted IQ Of About Half The U.S. Population, Study Says
TODAY’S SCOOP:
A
new study

finds that the expanded Child Tax Credit (CTC) — monthly cash payments to families — implemented last year did not negatively impact employment among adults with children. The data show  that Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) was completely wrong about the federal benefit’s impact on workforce numbers.
Last October, Sen. Manchin
tried to water down
President Biden’s enhanced CTC, urging a strict work requirement and a family income cap of $60,000 — a proposal that would have kicked more than
37 million children

off of the expanded benefit, including 190,000 in his home state alone. Manchin’s efforts were pinned on his ill-informed theory that expanding the payments would lead to fewer people wanting to work.

But the new paper, published this month by the National Bureau of Economic Research, reveals “that the CTC expansion had no meaningful impact on employment and labor force participation after six months of benefit distribution.” Moreover, according to the study’s authors, “the CTC expansion had no significant effect on employment and labor force participation for the lowest-income groups, which benefited most from the CTC expansion.”

Importantly, the study does reiterate earlier findings that the expanded CTC “strongly reduced child poverty” and “strongly reduced food insufficiency,” ultimately leading to “improved well-being for families with children.” According to Columbia University's Center on Poverty and Social Policy, nearly
3.7 million children
fell into poverty in January after Congress allowed the expanded credit to expire.
Congress failed to extend the CTC past December, in part due to Manchin’s callous rhetoric, which included
questioning
whether parents would use CTC payments to buy drugs. In fact, a Bureau of Labor Statistics report found that the number of people with jobs actually increased
1.5 percent
after receiving the credit.
TODAY’S STAT:
According to

Anthony Zenkus, a professor at Columbia University’s School of Social Work, “The United States has been at war for 225 of the 246 years it's been in existence.” That means the country has been at war for more than 90 percent of the time it’s been a nation, noted Zenkus, adding, “ No other nation on earth comes close. It's basically all we do.”
TODAY’S FLASHBACK:
Yesterday, people around the world observed International Women’s Day, a celebration adopted by the West in 1975. The day was
established
by the USSR in 1917 as International Working Women’s Day. The U.S.
dropped
the word “working” from their version.
TODAY’S CLICKS:
“TWO SEPARATE SYSTEMS OF LAW ENFORCEMENT”
: The Internal Revenue Service — the agency responsible for policing tax crime — audited Americans earning less than $25,000 at five times the rate of everyone else, according to
new findings

from the Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse at Syracuse University. “Does it make sense from either an equity or revenue standpoint to focus IRS’s limited firepower on the poorest taxpayers among us — those with incomes so low they have filed returns claiming an anti-poverty earned income tax credit?” the report asked. Last year,
The Daily Poster
reported
that the IRS’s budget has steeply declined as a percentage of the economy’s overall size, and that the agency’s audits of the wealthiest Americans have fallen dramatically and disproportionately.
POLITICIANS BOUGHT ENERGY STOCKS AHEAD OF UKRAINE INVASION:
A new
report

from unusualwhales.com finds that several U.S. lawmakers who serve on committees privy to private information — including Defense and Energy — recently bought energy stocks for the first time. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.)
bought
American oil stocks, war stocks, and renewable energy stocks one day before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, at the same time
tweeting

about how “War and rumors of war is incredibly profitable and convenient.” In response to the news of MTG buying stock in Lockheed Martin — the nation’s largest defense contractor — Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.)
tweeted
that there will soon be a hearing on banning federal lawmakers from trading stock in office.
TAX JUSTICE ORGS URGE MORE FEDERAL FUNDING TO ENFORCE SANCTIONS:
On Tuesday, the Financial Accountability & Corporate Transparency (FACT) Coalition — a nonpartisan alliance of more than 100 organizations working toward a fair tax system — issued a
press release

urging Congress to greenlight $118 million in funding for the Treasury Department to effectively enforce U.S. sanctions on Russian oligarchs. Last Spring, President Biden submitted as part of his FY 2022 budget request nearly $75 million in funding for the Treasury Department to carry out rulemaking efforts aimed at combating money laundering — a proposal that was met with
lawmakers’ calls

to further boost funding for this purpose. “If political leaders who say they want to catch oligarchs’ yachts are serious, now is the time to put their money where their mouth is,” said Erica Hanichak, FACT’s government affairs director. “This is an unprecedented opportunity to rein in the financial corruption that supports Russia’s war.”
IT’S ALL A GAME TO THEM:
On Tuesday, Paul Begala, a former top advisor to President Bill Clinton, teamed up with Reince Preibus, former President Donald Trump’s chief of staff, for a
special pundit debate show

at the 2022 conference of the Federation of American Hospitals — a lobbying group representing pricy investor-owned hospital chains. Moderating the panel was Chip Kahn, the federation’s CEO and a key architect in the plot to nix health care reform under Clinton. Kahn reportedly created the “Harry and Louise”
ad series
warning about the pitfalls of government-run health care. More recently, Kahn has
taken credit for
forming the Partnership for America’s Health Care Future, the front group campaigning against Medicare for All and a public health insurance option.
AMAZON RAINFOREST’S WANING RESILIENCE IS IMPACTING CLIMATE CHANGE:

New research shows that the Amazon is increasingly struggling to recover from droughts, deforestation, and other changes, which could transform more of the world’s largest rainforest into grassland and significantly impact climate change. “Losing the rainforest could result in up to 90 billion tons of heat-trapping carbon dioxide getting put back into the atmosphere, equivalent to several years of global emissions,” according to
recent reporting
from
The New York Times
. Scientists advocate for an end to deforestation in order to save the Amazon.
PROFIT-DRIVEN PHYSICIAN MANAGEMENT HIKED ANESTHESIOLOGY COSTS:
According to a
new study
, anesthesiology costs substantially rose after hospitals contracted with private equity-backed physician management companies. Moreover, the paper — published last month in the
Journal of the American Medical Association

— revealed that the growing trend of outsourcing anesthesiology management to profit-driven firms can hurt patients in the form of increased premiums and copays, and the moves don’t necessarily benefit physicians either. “Many states have corporate-practice-of-medicine laws that theoretically ban non-physician corporations from employing physicians, but these laws are easily circumvented,” Lawrence Casalino, one of the researchers,
explained
. “It may be time to reevaluate and either eliminate or strengthen them.”
TODAY’S OWN:

children.html:
a vote-blue-no-matter-who guy, never having had a single thought about Ukraine until 10 days ago, changes his twitter avatar to a wheat field in Kherson Oblast and leaves dozens of bad yelp reviews at local Russian restaurants... this is, I think, as American as politics can get

— Sam Adler-Bell (@SamAdlerBell) March 8, 2022

's work.
